<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
1 A thin solid disc of radius \(r\) and thickness \(z\) is attached to a thin axle. String is wrapped around the axle, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 117, 780, 385]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 404, 532, 421]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 435, 474, 452]]<|/det|>
A block of mass \(m\) is attached to the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 466, 918, 481]]<|/det|>
The block is released from rest and falls downwards. The block has speed \(v\) when it has fallen through a distance \(h\) from the point of release. The value of \(v\) is determined using one light gate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 497, 294, 512]]<|/det|>
connected to a timer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 526, 570, 544]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(v\) is related to \(m\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 554, 576, 587]]<|/det|>
\[
\frac{h}{v^{2}}=\frac{\pi r^{2} z}{2 P Q m}+\frac{1}{P}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 593, 366, 608]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 624, 695, 641]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(v\) and \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 655, 625, 672]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 685, 703, 703]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 716, 382, 733]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 747, 393, 764]]<|/det|>
- the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 776, 410, 791]]<|/det|>
- the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 806, 347, 821]]<|/det|>
- the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 833, 352, 852]]<|/det|>
- the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 862, 446, 879]]<|/det|>
- any safety precautions to be taken.

5.raw_output:
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 921, 91]]<|/det|>
2 A student investigates a circuit containing capacitors. The circuit is connected with a capacitor of capacitance \(A\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 117, 627, 425]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 441, 532, 458]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 472, 802, 488]]<|/det|>
Two capacitors, each of capacitance \(C\), are connected in parallel between P and Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 503, 634, 518]]<|/det|>
Initially, switch X and switch Z are closed and switch Y is open.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 533, 918, 549]]<|/det|>
Switches X and Z are opened. Switch Y is then closed. The maximum potential difference between P and Q is measured using the voltmeter. This procedure is repeated and the mean maximum

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 564, 565, 581]]<|/det|>
potential difference \(V\) between \(P\) and \(Q\) is determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 595, 918, 612]]<|/det|>
The experiment is then repeated by changing the number \(n\) of capacitors, each of capacitance \(C\), connected in parallel between P and Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 642, 570, 657]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(V\) and \(n\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 673, 565, 688]]<|/det|>
\[
E A=V(n C+A)
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 702, 581, 719]]<|/det|>
where \(E\) is the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 731, 659, 761]]<|/det|>
(a) A graph is plotted of \(\frac{1}{V}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(n\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 769, 611, 785]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[472, 875, 590, 926]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{array}{r}
\text { gradient }= \\
y \text {-intercept }=
\end{array}
\]
